abstract.p: New up-scale cosmetic remover towlettes noted; photo (Pulse column) (S)

block.p: In a time of luxury everything, the lowliest items are being dressed up and taken out. Even the humble Handi Wipe is going posh, with a new selection of upscale towelettes, manufactured by cosmetics companies for women who want a fancier freshen-up.

Last month, Stila introduced H2Off, green-tea-infused ''cleansing cloths'' in a sleek silvery oval container (above, $18 for 40 at Barneys New York), designed for makeup removal and other brow-blotting.

Last month, Stila introduced H2Off, green-tea-infused ''cleansing cloths'' in a sleek silvery oval container (above, $18 for 40 at Barneys New York), designed for makeup removal and other brow-blotting.

This month, M.A.C. will introduce its Lingettes Demaquillantes (French for . . . Wet-Nap?), perfumed musliny sheets intended to ''remove makeup, erase mistakes or refresh skin'' ($12.50 for 40 at all M.A.C. stores). And in September, Chanel will come clean with its Lotion Tendre Express Refreshing Swipes ($22.50 for 30 at all Chanel stores), cleaning tissues soaked in Precision Soothing Toner, aloe vera and bioecolia, a plant extract that is said to maintain the skin's natural bacteriologic balance.

To be sure, the new fancy wipes are prettier, softer and smell better than the average cleaner-upper you get at Red Lobster. Still, for portable makeup and stain removal, you can't beat a Huggies baby wipe, $3.89 for 85, at local drugstores.
